title: Wednesday, 22nd June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

Hey. Hello. Good morning.

BE

And we knew this day would come.

BE

The sacred texts foretold it.

11:04 am
BE

A day when their flesh shall rot away while they stand upon their feet

BE

.... and their eyes shall rot away in their sockets, and their tongue shall rot away in their mouths.

BE

And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great panic shall be among them

11:04 am
BE

.... and they shall lay hold everyone on the hand of his neighbour, and his hand shall rise up against the hand of his neighbour.

BE

And the wealth of all the heathen round about shall be gathered together, for it shall come to pass that every one that is left of all the nations shall be smited by a mighty vengeance.

BE

The punishment of all peoples and all nations.

11:05 am
BE

That is.

BE

Albert.

BE

Edwards.

11:05 am
BE

On.

BE

Brexit.

BE

The UK referendum is neck and neck. Commentators think it so close that the deciding factor could be whether it rains on Thursday – with rain seen reducing the Remain vote. How mad is that? One year ago we wrote that the UK economy was a ticking time bomb. The ticking has got even louder. The UK economy is a mess and that has nothing to do with Brexit – it has everything to do with economic mismanagement. We studiously take no view on the outcome of the vote; we simply discuss the possible implications of a sharp decline in sterling in the event of Brexit. But there is an argument that global investors have overly focused on Brexit at the expense of other more important macro events. We believe China’s ongoing stealth devaluation of the renminbi is far more important for the global economy.

11:06 am
BE

So SocGen's head of doom has been reading Soros -- https://www.thegua...dards-george-soros -- and thinks he's far too optimistic.

BE

The Soros article makes it clear he believes the UK will not benefit from a substantial sterling decline in the event of Brexit, in the same way it did in the aftermath of the September 1992 ejection of sterling from the ERM quite the reverse. Boiling his highly eloquent argument down to its essence, Soros thinks the key is that interest rates fell substantially subsequent to Black Wednesday, from 10% the day before to just 6% only three months later. He does not believe monetary policy will be eased subsequent to a Brexit. Second, the UK has a very large current account deficit (see chart below) and Brexit will cause funding pressure resulting in capital flight. Third, post-Brexit uncertainty will prevent higher investment and jobs growth to take advantage of the weaker sterling, and the UK would be left with a sharp squeeze on household incomes due to higher import prices.

BE

George Soros may well be right. But thinking about this from the point of view of my Ice Age thesis, where interest rates cannot be normalised because of economic weakness and deflation pressures persisting throughout this recovery, I would have thought a 20% sterling devaluation is exactly the antidote needed in the current circumstances. Yes of course a fall in sterling increases import prices and squeezes household real incomes, but the booming profits companies enjoy from a weaker sterling should generate a virtuous wage price spiral and take us away from the deflationary abyss that awaits all developed economies in the next recession. This is exactly what Abenomics was all about in Japan. Hence I would be much more positive about the immediate post-Brexit economic outlook than Mr Soros.

11:07 am
BE

Where I do agree is that the UK current account deficit is huge, reaching 5.2% of GDP for 2015 as a whole the largest peacetime deficit since 1832 (the deficit incidentally is entirely due to the UKs imbalance with the rest of the EU). In the final quarter of last year the deficit ballooned out to 7% of GDP wow! And that is not all. There is another key deficit problem.
For in sharp contrast to other countries and Chancellor Osbornes rhetoric, there has been an almost total lack of discretionary fiscal tightening in the UK (see chart below). The UK economy is a mess see The UK is a ticking time bomb. I think sterling will end up falling substantially whether the UK stays or leaves the EU it is just a matter of timing.

BE

(@ROTR: Loosely, Zechariah. You're all going to hell.)

BE

Want the chart? Have the chart.

11:08 am
BE

undefined
BE

Incidentally, we're running a 36 hour Brexit liveblog tomorrow.

11:10 am
BE

I'm in to cover the back shift tomorrow,, post close of the markets to close of the polls, when there's absolutely nothing to say.

BE

With Sarah O'Connor scheduled to be Paul Murphy, if one can imagine such a thing.

BE

Do come over and say hello.

11:11 am
BE

As to today, though, we're up again.

BE

Cable nearly at a five-month high.

BE

FTSE ahead 0.3%.

11:11 am
BE

20 points better at 6246.

BE

If I search my email for "calm before the storm" I get about 600 hits from this morning.

BE

(@Rushian: don't.)

11:13 am
BE

So rather than getting bogged down in polls of polls and shy status quo fans and etc, we can go to the movers.

BE

(Though feel free to talk about the Great Debate or whatever on the right. If you really want.)

BE

Leading us down is AB Foods.

11:14 am
Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,810, down 90.85 (-3.13%), High: 2,870, Low: 2,804, Volume: 315.23k
BE

Morgan Stanley downgrade, from the consistently excellent Geoff Ruddell.

BE

Who sent it out overnight, so everyone had the chance to digest it fully.

11:16 am
BE

It begins with a question.

BE

Primark is so freaking cheap ....

BE

11:16 am
BE

... so, why's its LFL turning negative?

BE

BE

Geoff kicks that question around for 39 pages, and concludes "dunno". Though it's an interesting "dunno".

11:17 am
BE

To recap, Primark only has 170 stores in the UK.

BE

And hardly any new ones opening. Total floorspace has barely changed since 2014.

BE

... Perhaps because it's not that easy to find high footfall prime 40,000 sqf sites.

11:17 am
BE

So, growth has been in Continental Europe, where the revenue per square foot is even better than the UK.

BE

(About €800 per sq ft, MOST estimates, versus a £500 group average.)

BE

But! Each new opening cannibalises that.

11:18 am
BE

The Italians and Spaniards and such are apparently travelling up to two hours to get to their nearest Primark.

BE

Stick one closer and -- to state the obvious -- they won't travel so far. Nor will they be compelled to spend so much.

BE

Plus, there's not that much expansion before Europe hits the "lack of high footfall prime 40,000 sqf sites" problem again, not least because there are surprisingly few big malls on the Continent.

11:20 am
BE

Europe looks to hit the same growth ceiling as in the UK in three to five years, according to MOST.

BE

So. That puts a lot of AB's value on its US expansion.

BE

Where Primark is also freaking cheap

11:20 am
BE

BE

And where there's no particular shortage of malls.

BE

But!

11:20 am
BE

Primark only opened its third US store on June 10.

BE

And trading the first two -- Boson and Philadelphia -- doesn't look that great.

BE

The Philly store "has had periods of softness" and brand awareness was "lower I think than we'd anticipated", Weston said after the last results in April.

11:21 am
BE

It'd be insensible to assume Primark will fail in the US. But it'd also be brave to assume much from Primark's US business before 2019.

BE

Leaving a quite long interlude where UK and Europe LFL turns negative.

BE

Perhaps quite sharply, if Kantar data's to be believed.

11:22 am
BE

(Data are to be believed. Sorry to any pedants reading.)

BE

BE

Why's this happening? Dunno.

11:23 am
BE

Might be Primark's lack of online. (You can't sell online at an average unit price of £4.)

BE

Or it might just be that Primark's hit UK saturation.

BE

Here's a terrifying stat: one in seven items of clothing are purchased in Primark.

11:23 am
BE

One in six if you exclude online.

BE

BE

As we know, it does this through extremely high sales densities.

11:24 am
BE

BE

Leading MOST to a question I've never seen in sellside research before: do people hate the company?

BE

Are Primark's stores becoming so busy that they are becoming almost 'unshoppable'?

11:25 am
BE

It is hard to provide a definitive answer to this question, but our survey work would certainly suggest that the instore environment is becoming an issue for many consumers. This was first brought home to us at a focus group panel we attended last year when the moderator asked panelists to describe how they felt after leaving a Primark store and they suggested that it was "relief"!

BE

Anyway.

BE

To recap .......

11:25 am
BE

Site expansion's ended in the UK and becoming tricky abroad, sales densities are maxxed out, LFL's at risk of going ex growth, and everything's hanging on an entirely unproven market.

BE

Which isn't to say Primark has suddenly turned into M&S. It hasn't.

BE

But there's a big difference between being a 10% CAGR business and a 20% CAGR business.

11:26 am
BE

Although we see no reason why Primark should not continue to deliver c10% space growth each year, we think it increasingly optimistic to expect it to deliver anywhere close to the 4.6% LfL growth it has averaged since 2000. We now see Primark as a 10-12% EBIT growth business, not one capable of growing at 15-20%. Because of the power of compounding, this makes a big difference to our valuation work.

BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily you know.

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,813, down 88 (-3.03%), High: 2,870, Low: 2,804, Volume: 325.18k
11:27 am
BE

(@fjp73: I don't know the answer to that.)

BE

(@fjp73: and I give a mere flavour of the product. There's plenty of stuff in there about cruising stores trying to work out if there are operational problems.)

undefined
11:28 am
BE

Was someone badgering us about Elementis?

BE

Profit warning.

Elementis PLC (ELM:LSE): Last: 208.11, down 18.29 (-8.08%), High: 213.30, Low: 186.00, Volume: 2.69m
11:29 am
BE

Continuation of previous problems, really. Chromium the issue.

BE

“below the range of market expectations” means 10% off consensus, in market-eze.

BE

(@Rushian: ... and to answer your earlier question, I guess we could build a bot to machine read these things. But it won't be one that makes you rich.)

11:31 am
BE

Here comes Caz to summarise where forecasts are going.

BE

Elementis has issued a trading update ahead of its H1 results which are to
be announced on August 2nd. The company has guided for EPS this year to
be “below the range of market expectations” as a result of continued
weakness in Chromium. Market conditions outside of North America are
expected to remain challenging due to currency weakness against the US
dollar, particularly in Eastern Europe. As a result, sales and margins
outside of North America for the year as a whole are expected to be
“materially lower than the previous year”. Of the other divisions, Specialty
Products has continued to make progress, with coatings and personal care
continuing to grow and oilfield stable. The company expects strong
cashflow generation to continue and net cash to improve year on year. We
expect a c.10% downgrade to Bloomberg consensus EPS estimates based
on lower chromium estimates.

BE

Chromium facing challenges outside of North America. In
Chromium, sales and contribution margins in North America are
expected to be “similar” to the previous year. However, conditions
outside of North America have remained challenging – due to Eastern
European currency weakness against the USD – and, as such, sales and
margins outside of the region are expected to be down “materially” year
on year. The Kazakh Tenge and the Russian Ruble have both further
depreciated against the USD this year. The current spot KZT/USD
exchange rate is down c.33% over 2015 average and the current
RUB/USD has fallen 3.5% vs. 2015 average.

11:32 am
BE

Remainder of the business on track. Aside from Chromium, Specialty
Products has continued to make progress in line with the IMS issued post
Q1. Within Specialty Products, sales in Asia have resumed a growth
trend, oilfield has stabilized and personal care continued to show
“impressive” growth. The cash flow profile of the group appears to have
remained strong and the net cash balance is expected to improve year on
year at the year end.

BE

And N+1, which is shop.

BE

Elementis’ H1 pre-close update highlights further pressures within Chromium export markets. The relative strength of the US dollar has created a challenging competitive environment in Eastern Europe in particular and, as a result, Chromium sales and margins outside of North America are expected to be materially lower than the previous year. Despite good progress in Specialties and a steady performance from Chromium in North America, earnings per share for the year as a whole will fall below previous expectations. We reduce our PBT and EPS forecasts by 12% in all three forecast years, assuming no recovery in Chromium over the period. One strong positive in the announcement is confirmation that the net cash position at the end of the year is still expected to be ahead of the prior year (implying no change to DPS forecasts), which should provide support, given the implied 5% yield.

11:34 am
BE

... brief pause while I try and find someone who's not shop.

BE

............. Nope.

undefined
11:36 am
BE

There was also a request, unless I'm mistaken, for Debenhams.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 71.10, down 3.15 (-4.24%), High: 72.70, Low: 69.60, Volume: 3.56m
BE

Q3 sales as weak as you'd expect.

11:38 am
BE

For which we can blame weather and ... uh, Brexit, I guess. People not buying frocks in anticipation of the referendum.

BE

LFL was -0.2% v consensus flat.

BE

Or -1.6% LFL on constant FX.

11:39 am
BE

What's more interesting, perhaps, is that gross margin's not improved from the first half.

BE

You'll remember management's endless talk about rolling back promotions and etc.

BE

Today we get a mention of higher concession sales and "tactical promotions"

11:40 am
BE

Oh, and online sales are up just 7%.

BE

Underperforming the market.

BE

The bounce from Debs throwing a lot of money at next-day delivery seems to have dissipated very quickly.

11:41 am
BE

(There may be a school uniform effect here. Dunno.)

BE

Here's Deutsche Bank to talk us through it all.

BE

A slowdown in UK trading was not unexpected but more significant than we
had modeled, with gross margin guidance also being lowered. Hence our full
year Aug-16 Headline PBT falls by 4.4% from £118m to £113m, equivalent to a
20% cut in H2 forecasts. The company continues to make progress with its
strategic goals, but given the challenges to growing profits we maintain Hold.

11:42 am
BE

Debenhams reported constant currency like for like sales growth of -1.6% for
the 15 weeks to 11 June. Although not disclosed, we estimate this to include
UK LFLs of -2.2% (or -2.9% excluding online). Kantar Worldpanel data confirms
that Debenhams in holding share (see: “April Showers. May flowers”, 7 June).
Management thinks that changing consumer patterns - shifting more to
holidays, eating out and experiences - is more of an explanatory factor for
weak clothing market than the weather or political uncertainty. However, it
acknowledged that the changing calendar of events and the consumer
backdrop had made trading patterns volatile and hard to read.

BE

Gross margin guidance for the full financial year was lowered to “flat” from “0
to +50bps”, implying a small decline in H2 margins. However, management
confirmed that H2 markdown would be better year on year, just not by as
much as expected. Operating cost growth for the year is expected to be at the
bottom of the guided range of +2% to +4%. This implies that H2 costs will be
c.£10m lower than we had previously forecast, a quite substantial shift
reflecting tight control in head office, stores, the benefit of systems investment
and click & collect lowering the cost of online fulfillment.

BE

We expect Aug-16 Headline PBT of £113.1m, broadly flat on last year
(£113.5m) and the prior year (£110.3m). In the year ahead one swing factor
may be the outcome of the Examinership in Ireland: in FY Aug-15 the division
lost €6.7m and is one reason why we forecast group profits to grow to £120m.

11:42 am
BE

Our target price, lowered from 85p to 80p, continues to be based on DCF
(WACC 8.5%, RFR 4.5%, ERP 4.5%, beta 1.1, all assumptions in line with those
used for other stocks in the sector), and terminal growth of -1% to reflect
Debenhams' maturity profile. In our view, upside risks include success of a
number of current initiatives which are designed to boost profitable sales.
Downside risks relate to the need to continue investing, both opex and capex,
or increased competitive intensity in the mid-market led by an M&S revival.

BE

And ................ Citi? Citi.

BE

Citi's Take

At -1.6% Group LFL, Debenhams 3Q LFL is slightly below our expectations but should be seen in the context of a weak UK clothing market through the period. A combination of gross margin guidance being revised down, but also lower costs growth is likely to result in consensus FY16 PBT reducing by c2-3%. Despite this, cash generation remains solid with Debenhams reiterating its FY16 net debt guidance of £270m - £290m.

3Q group ccy LFL -1.6%, slightly below forecast (Citi LFL +1.5%)

For the 15-week period ended 11 June, group LFL sales were -1.6% (constant currency) reflecting a weaker trading environment in the UK, particularly Womenswear, partly offset by continuing growth in Health and Beauty. Performance in International has been mixed with constant currency sales still positive in the period, but a slowdown in growth at Magasin du Nord, reflecting similar trends in Denmark to the UK.

Online sales growth +7% yoy

Online sales were +7% yoy versus the c.+10% growth seen through 1H, but reflects a tougher comparative last year. Trends in mobile remain positive (over 50% of UK online orders) and Click & Collect growth remained strong +19% yoy.

11:43 am
BE

FY16 guidance

Gross margin guidance has been revised down to flat from flat to +50bp previously (Citi +10bp), reflecting more tactical promotional responses given the tougher trading environment and dilutive product mix effects (Health & Beauty, gifting etc. growing faster vs higher margin clothing). Cost growth for FY16 is now expected to be at the lower end of the +2-4% range (Citi +2.6%).

FY16 inventory, expect clean seasonal stock position

Having tightened the initial buy, seasonal stocks will be managed through selected promotional activity with Debenhams expecting to end the year with a clean stock position.

Implications

FY16 consensus PBT likely to reduce by c 2-3% — On the back of the slightly softer revenue and gross margin trends but better cost control guidance we expect consensus FY16 PBT forecasts (range of £113m - £121m, midpoint £117m) to reduce by c2-3%. We have an August 2016 PBT forecast of £117m (EPS 7.6p,flat yoy).

Space optimisation programme on track

Debenhams remains on track to fill 75% (50% at 1H) of the 1m sqft of identified space for Christmas peak.

Buy, target price 90p

Our TP is based on a 9.5x target EV/EBIT multiple for FY17e, equating to c.11x PE and c.4% dividend yield in the same year-end.

undefined
BE

(Everybody's standin' round my desk. Talkin' 'bout the referendum. I can't hear a word I'm thinking ...)

11:45 am
BE

Okay! What else?

BE

(@Boncoeur: ..... and one still refers to Fleet Street, which is now Goldman Sachs and about 17 branches of Pret. Epithets don't need retain meaning providing they still make sense.)

BE

Hornby? Sure.

11:47 am
Hornby PLC (HRN:LSE): Last: 31.79, up 0.4311 (+1.37%), High: 31.79, Low: 29.00, Volume: 59.63k
BE

Prints a FY loss, raises £8m with a placing.

BE

To refocus on Scalextric, Airfix and Corgi post a stinker of a year, when too much stuff went into the January sales.

11:49 am
BE

Those are the headlines. Let me see if anyone still covers it.

BE

Here's the statement, incidentally. http://www.investe...1606220700078922B/

BE

Numis broker, and I assume are restricted.

11:51 am
BE

No other sellside on it, so you're on your own. Sorry about that.

undefined
BE

(@fjp73: you try to wrap up an app as a birthday present.)

11:53 am
BE

("Physical toys" are the youth equivalent of scented candles. People give them a lot more than they're used.)

BE

Sheesh, it's quiet again. Quick scout around sellside I guess.

BE

Goldman downgrade of InterContinental is something to note.

11:54 am
InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 2,641, down 9.5 (-0.36%), High: 2,643, Low: 2,610, Volume: 345.84k
BE

.... even if it's had no particular effect.

BE

Perhaps because the reasons are well known already.

11:55 am
BE

We downgrade IHG to Neutral from Buy following further deceleration in
2Q16 US RevPAR (2Q16 qtd: 2.2%, 1Q16: 2.7%, 4Q15: 4.8%), which leads
us to lower earnings expectations (2016-18E EPS cut 3%-9%). We expect
IHG’s 2016 RevPAR growth to decelerate to 1.4% (2015: 4.4%) and forecast
no EBIT growth in 2016. Medium term, however, we see IHG’s low capital
intensity (asset light model) as attractive and expect its 6.2% CY17E adj.
FCFy to provide support to its current valuation, particularly in the context
of a 15% 2016-19E FCF CAGR. Since being added to the Buy List on
December 3, 2010, the stock is up 117% vs. FTSE World Europe up 7.9%.

BE

While recent steps to increase regulation on peer-to-peer lodging sites such
as Airbnb (short-term rental of entire apartments prohibited in Berlin and
potentially in New York) may halt their pace of growth, medium term, we
still see these sites as a headwind to traditional hotels’ RevPAR growth. On
our estimates, c.2pp pa of London RevPAR growth comes through price
increases on compression nights, which could be at risk from Airbnb
(particularly in gateway cities over summer). We cut our 2017-19 RevPAR
forecasts by 0.8pp pa, as we expect IHG to offset some impact through
improved revenue management. Similarly, its strong share of the global
hotel pipeline (15%) means system growth should accelerate to 3.6% pa
over 2016-19E, in part offsetting our lower RevPAR forecasts, while its
business-focused guests, best-in-class loyalty programme, and high level of
direct bookings (2015: OTA bookings 13.8%) should limit disintermediation.

BE

IHG trades on a CY16E P/E of 20.7x and 4.9% adj. FCFy, above its historical
average (12m fwd since 2012) of 19.2x, consistent with higher forecast
growth (12% EPS CAGR 2016-19E vs. 7.5% 2012-15) and returns (CY17E
ROIC: 31%), in our view. Our 12-month PT decreases to 3,090p from 3,440p
owing to estimate changes, and is based on growth and returns (RevPAR
and ROIC) and includes a 15% M&A weighting; 17% upside.

11:57 am
BE

("Party present lists", ROTR? Really? Anyone who sends out such a thing is getting a genuine Crazy Frog with the batteries superglued in.)

BE

Risks: stronger/weaker RevPAR, FX moves, higher/lower supply growth.

BE

So, that.

11:58 am
undefined
BE

While on Goldman, there seems to be some confusion about that Ocado note they sent out.

BE

On Monday.

11:59 am
BE

A few market reports picked it up on Tuesday.

BE

The wires seem to be picking it up today.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 249.90, up 4.5 (+1.83%), High: 253.80, Low: 243.10, Volume: 391.17k
12:00 pm
BE

Which is ........ odd. Not least because it says nothing Goldman hasn't said 100 times before.

BE

Namely, "we stuffed our clients with this, and they want out again."

BE

I paraphrase slightly.

12:01 pm
BE

Following the GS Equity Radar: Acquiring Future Leadership (June 20) and
with Ocado trading at 1x FY17E sales, 30% below its average since listing,
we remain of the view that Ocado will be viewed as an attractive M&A
target. As we have previously written (A non-food acquirer could unlock
substantial delivery savings, January 20, 2016), we believe Ocado could
unlock material delivery cost savings for a predominantly non-food
acquirer, while the Ocado Smart Platform means Ocado has already
worked out how to integrate itself into another retailer. Recent share price
weakness leaves the stock very attractively valued we believe.

BE

That's from Monday. MONDAY.

undefined
12:02 pm
BE

Is that midday already? It only feels like a few short hours since we started.

BE

Thanks for the comments, ROTR.

BE

We'll be back tomorrow, doing what we always do amidst what promises to be a wall of FT.com liveblogs.

12:03 pm
BE

Until then, cheerio.

BE

We now value Primark at £15.1bn (16.5x EBITDA) rather than £22.2bn previously. We do not make any material changes to our valuations of other divisions, but the lower Primark valuation leads us to reduce our ABF price target from 3,500p to 2,650p and our rating from Overweight to Equal-weight.
